title: Analysis | Trump’s claim that U.S. is only country with ‘thousands’ of immigration judges
subtitle: The president describes the U.S. immigration system as overly generous and "ridiculous." In fact, many countries follow the same process.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
“If one foot hits our country, we have to take those people gently, register them and then release them. Okay? We’re going to release them, essentially, in a short period of time. So we release them. And then they’re supposed to come for a court case. We hire more judges — we’re trying to hire thousands of judges. No other country in the world does it.”

 — Trump, during a roundtable on taxes in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., April 5, 2018

The Justice Department did not respond to our request for comment. An administration official emphasized that there’s an effort underway to hire more judges, as Trump said in April. “With many new judges being sworn in since the president took office, it reinforces the administration’s goals of reducing the massive backlog in the U.S. immigration courts,” the official said.

Immigration judges are not counted toward this total, since they work in the executive branch, inside the Justice Department. But the point is that all the Article III judges, hearing all sorts of federal cases, at all the different levels, only number at 1,300 or so — not in the thousands. Adding in immigration judges only gets you to 1,630 or so (also not in the thousands).

“I struggle to think of countries that don’t have some kind of adversarial process to determine who is a refugee,” Parker said. “Governments do have latitude to determine how they’re going to set up the process. Some governments rely on UNHCR to do the refugee status determination process. In the U.S., there are asylum offices who can do a status determination. There are also immigration judges who can make this determination.”

“Asylum seekers here go through a similar process as in other countries — there is an initial determination of whether the person meets the definition of a refugee and will be granted protection, and the opportunity to contest or appeal that decision,” Bell said. “This is at heart an adjudicatory process following administrative and case law. Whether before an immigration court or a tribunal, evidence is presented, lawyers may be present. Many Western nations use the equivalent of immigration courts to determine asylum status and whether an immigrant can be deported.”
